XBRL International is a global not for profit operating in the public interest. Our purpose is to improve the accountability and transparency of business performance globally, by providing the open data exchange standard for business reporting.

The Taxonomy Development Handbook (TDH) is a comprehensive guide that directs regulators, industry experts, and businesses through a practical, consistent roadmap to building high quality data standards using XBRL.

text: XBRL is a set of specifications
Description: List of XBRL technical specifications
Tutorial explaining basics of XML
XML Schema specifications
A good explanation of derivation in XML
XLink specifications
XPointer specifications
Glossary of XBRL terms
Core XBRL Specs
The XBRL Dimensions specification enables the reporting of multi-dimensional facts against dimensions defined in an XBRL taxonomy.
Allows for constraining the allowed values for primary reporting concepts (choices from specific list).
XBRL Formula provides a standard mechanism for defining rules in a taxonomy that can be applied against instance documents.
A link type with no predefined semantics or constraints. This can be used used as a building block for other specifications.
This specification introduces the preferred label feature for all relationships.
XBRL Specs for transactional reporting.
Specifications in this section are used to support the development of XBRL specifications and registries.
Inline XBRL, or iXBRL, provides a mechanism for embedding XBRL tags in HTML documents.
Registries provide a centralized list of definitions, allowing implementers to re-use suitable definitions created by others.
Provides a mechanism for taxonomy authors to define a tabular layout of facts. The resulting tables can be used for both presentation and data entry.
Taxonomy Packages provide a standardized mechanism for providing documentation about the content of a taxonomy.
Defines an XML syntax for an XBRL versioning Report.
Full guide for XULE used to validate and query XBRL instance documents.
